SOURCE_FILE: note_051.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION [REDACTED] is a 22-year-old female who presents with right middle lobe consolidation.

CONSENT The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient indicated a wish to proceed with surgery and informed consent was signed.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J98.4 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J98.4 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration tracheobronchial tree, initial episode (31645)

Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) (31624) 

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).

Initial Airway Inspection Findings: Mucoid impaction were identified in the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Right Middle Lobe.

Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Right Middle Lobe from mucoid impaction.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at the Lateral Segment of the RML (RB4) and the Medial Segment of the RML (RB5).

Instilled 100 cc of NS, suction returned with 40 cc of NS.

Samples sent for AFB, Fungal, and Routine Culture.

The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.

At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)

RML BAL (AFB, Fungal, and Routine Culture) 

IMPRESSION / PLAN

[REDACTED] is a 22-year-old female who presents for bronchoscopy for right middle lobe consolidation.

Therapeutic aspiration performed for mucus plugging.

RML BAL performed for microbiology.

Follow up in clinic.

We suctioned the airways and performed a BAL of the Superior Lingular Segment (LB4) and Inferior Lingular Segment (LB5). We used 120 cc of saline and got back 50 cc. Specimens sent for Microbiology/Viral/Fungal.

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION [REDACTED] is a 22-year-old male who presents with persistent atelectasis.

CONSENT The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient indicated a wish to proceed with surgery and informed consent was signed.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J84.10 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J84.10 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration tracheobronchial tree, initial episode (31645)

Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) (31624) 

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).

Initial Airway Inspection Findings: Mucus and mucus plugs were identified in the Left Mainstem and Lingular Bronchus.

Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Left Mainstem and Lingular Bronchus from mucus and mucus plugs.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at the Superior Lingular Segment (LB4) and Inferior Lingular Segment (LB5).

Instilled 120 cc of NS, suction returned with 50 cc of NS.

Samples sent for Microbiology/Viral/Fungal.

The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.

At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)

Lingula BAL (Microbiology/Viral/Fungal) 

IMPRESSION / PLAN

[REDACTED] is a 22-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for persistent atelectasis.

Therapeutic aspiration performed for mucus plugging.

Lingula BAL performed for microbiology.

Follow up in clinic.
